thread.title: EU referendum: What will happen to the North East's MEPs?
thread.title_full: EU referendum: What will happen to the North East's MEPs?

author: Michael Muncaster
title: EU referendum: What will happen to the North East's MEPs?
text:
The video will start in 8 s Cancel Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
Britain is set to leave the European Union after voters chose Brexit in the historic EU referendum . 
Voters in Gateshead, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland, County Durham and Northumberland all decided to back the Brexit campaign. 
In Newcastle, there was a narrow win - by 1,806 votes - for the region to remain in the EU. 
But there is still a lot of uncertainty over what exactly will happen next. 
We look at what the decision means for Britain’s 73 Members of European Parliament (MEPs)? What is an MEP? 
A MEP is someone who has been elected to serve as a popular representative in the European Parliament. 
They have the power to approve, amend or reject nearly all EU legislation. There are 751 MEPs and 73 represent the UK. Who are the MEPs for the North East? Jonathan Arnott MEP 
They are Labour MEPs Jude Kirton-Darling, and Paul Brannen, along with UKIP MEP Jonathan Arnott. 
Both Labour MEPs campaigned for Britain to stay in the EU, claiming the North East benefited more than any other region from European funding. 
But pro Brexit Mr Arnott called for Britain to leave because the UK had “a 100% record of failure” in trying to change EU laws. What does leaving the EU mean for our MEPs? 
Nobody knows. There is not a timeline in place for when Britain will leave the union so we don’t know when the MEPs will be heading home. 
The next MEP elections are due place in 2019 and there has been no official word on whether Britain’s representatives will depart before then. 
For now, the UK’s MEPs aren’t going anywhere as they are still elected officials with a job to do. How have the MEPs for the North East reacted to voters choosing Brexit? Paul Brannen 
Mr Arnott described the decision as a “tremendous day for Britain and for our democratic process”. 
He said: “The people of the North East have led the way in voting clearly for Brexit. 
“The British people as a whole have spoken and we have regained control over our own destiny. 
“Now the hard work begins. We must now deal with our European colleagues as friends and neighbours and negotiate a deal for the future which allows us to trade freely with the EU, control our borders and work together for our mutual benefit.” 
However, Mr Brannen tweeted: “The people have spoken. The turmoil begins. The poor will suffer. The rich will be fine. The country is reduced.” 
Mrs Kirton-Darling said she was “pretty broken-hearted” Britain had voted to leave. 
She tweeted: “That’s democracy. People are very angry and divided. We need to find a way to deal with it.” More on the EU Referendum
